title: Can i file chapter 7 bankruptcy if my income is benifits social security and retirement
question: My mother passed away a year ago and we shared bills in the same house when she passed away my life became a total wreck i had a good job till i had to stop working cause i becamr disabled to work and the money i recieved after that is just not enough i couldnt afford to pay rent on my own anywhere so my daughter let me move in rent free but with all my bills i still didnt even have enough to pay my meds i would always ask my son to help pay then my car broke down and i need my car to go to doctors appointment so i had to get installment loan to repiar it and and eventually i had to move out to my sister where i have to pay 500 a month for a room ive borrowed money witch i had to get another installment loan to pay people back plus i got payday loans also i only get 2000 month i cant even offord my health insuransce and meds i have diabeties and and have credit debt too i cant. Survive paying these bills im making myself sick what are my options?
answers: What the others have said. Plus, do yourself a big favor by getting a consultation with an experienced bankruptcy in your area.

Yes. Your source of income and the amount is one factor only when evaluating your options and deciding if filing for chapter 7 bankruptcy protection and relief offers a solution. Benefits and social security (income) as they compared to your current expenses must be considered, even if your social security may be exempt as income from means test analysis.

From the quick description you provide, you may very well be a strong candidate for filing bankruptcy, however you should always consult with an experienced professional to have your prospective case analyzed before making a final decision.

Bankruptcy lawyers should be able to help you evaluate the many factors weighing in on your choice to file, which also includes your assets, the nature of debts and to what extent dischargeable, any pre-Bankruptcy transfers, and a variety of possible pitfalls to be aware of.

Social Security benefits are no considered in the income qualifications for chapter 7. Your retirement income is the income that would be considered if you qualify for chapter 7 relief. Based on the information you provided it would appear you qualify.
Seek a consultation with a qualified bankruptcy attorney in your area.

Filing a bankruptcy case would help by discharging the unsecured debts that you are now unable to pay, but the bankruptcy case is not going to help you with housing, food, medical insurance, medications, etc. You may want to first start by contacting Alameda County Social Services, and find out if you qualify for Medi-Cal, subsidized housing, Cal-Fresh or other benefits. You may have to stop making payments on debts if you cannot afford the payments on your current income. Once you come to a point where you don't have to borrow money for living expenses and medical expenses, contact a bankruptcy attorney in your area for a consultation about chapter 7 bankruptcy.
